Title:
Effect of different speciation modes on divergence dating â
implication for speciation history of Takydromus grass lizard
Keywords: divergence time, grass, lizard, speciation, gene flow
Abstract:
Investigation of divergence time and speciation process
are central issues in evolutionary biology, but notoriously difficult in
non-model organisms. The difficulty is rooted in variations in ancestral
population size, or variations in separation history across loci. In
order to depict speciation process and divergent history of three
monophyletic Takydromus species endemic to Taiwan, 20 nuclear and one
mitochondrial loci were used for divergence time estimation by using
multispecies coalescent approach under Bayesian framework. Divergence
dating based on gene tree approach showed great variation among loci and
the results were more ancient than that derived by species tree
approach. To test whether variations in ancestral population size
account for the majority of above observations, i.e., whether gene flow
has to be invoked during speciation, we conducted computer simulation
under isolation-with-migration (IM) and approximate Bayesian computation
(ABC) frameworks. The results revealed that gene flow during the early
stage of speciation was strongly favored over isolation model and the
initiation of speciation process was far more ancient that gene- and
species-based divergence dating. Due to their limited dispersal ability,
it is suggested that geographic isolation may have played a major role
in divergent process of Takydromus spp. Nevertheless, current study
reveals a far more complex situation and demonstrates gene flow during
speciation process cannot be overlooked and may have great impact on
divergence dating.
